item.title: Split Over Donald Trump Threatens to Tilt Republican States
item.media:description: Donald J. Trump speaking to supporters on Tuesday night in Panama City Beach, Fla.
item.description: Democrats are aiming to run up a big margin of victory for Hillary Clinton and extend their political advantage into the congressional elections next month.
item.dc:creator: ALEXANDER BURNS and JONATHAN MARTIN

item.title: Donald Trump Berates Paul Ryan and ‘Disloyal’ Republicans
item.media:description: Donald J. Trump spoke to supporters at a rally in Wilkes Barre, Pa. on Monday. He called House Speaker Paul D. Ryan a “weak and ineffective leader” in a Twitter post on Tuesday.
item.description: On Twitter, Mr. Trump criticized Republicans who had withdrawn support after a recording of him demeaning women became public.
item.dc:creator: ALAN RAPPEPORT

item.title: Donald Trump Faltering? Die-Hard Fans Refuse to Buy It
item.media:description: Attendees at Donald J. Trump’s rally in Wilkes-Barre, Pa., on Monday.
item.description: At Mr. Trump’s rallies, the candidate and the crowds draw energy and affirmation from one another, while dismissing any discouraging information.
item.dc:creator: TRIP GABRIEL

item.title: Group’s Tactic on Hillary Clinton: Sue Her Again and Again
item.media:description: Tom Fitton, the president of Judicial Watch, at the group’s offices in Washington. The organization has long been an antagonist of Hillary and Bill Clinton.
item.media:credit: Justin T. Gellerson for The New York Times
item.description: The nonprofit organization Judicial Watch has more than 20 active lawsuits involving the Democratic nominee, and has focused on the Clintons since its formation in 1994.
item.dc:creator: JONATHAN MAHLER

item.title: The 2016 Race: How One 19-Year-Old Illinois Man Is Distorting National Polling Averages
item.media:description: Donald Trump supporters in Panama City Beach, Fla., this week.
item.description: The U.S.C/Los Angeles Times poll has consistently been an outlier, showing Donald Trump in the lead or near the lead.
item.dc:creator: NATE COHN

item.title: Donald Trump Is ‘Dangerous’ for Global Stability, U.N. Rights Chief Says
item.media:description: Zeid Ra’ad al-Hussein, the United Nations high commissioner for human rights, in Geneva on Wednesday.
item.description: Zeid Ra’ad al-Hussein, the high commissioner for human rights, doubled down on remarks he gave last month condemning “nationalist demagogues.”
item.dc:creator: NICK CUMMING-BRUCE

item.title: Billy Bush Negotiating Exit From NBC After Lewd Tape
item.media:description: Billy Bush joined the “Today” show over the summer.
item.description: The “Today” host is negotiating his departure after the release of a video in which he cheered on Donald J. Trump as he made vulgar comments about women.
item.dc:creator: JOHN KOBLIN

item.title: Pentagon Confronts a New Threat From ISIS: Exploding Drones
item.media:description: Eric Fanning, the secretary of the Army, right, earlier this month in Washington. Mr. Fanning recently assigned a special office he had created to respond to emerging threats and to study how to stop drones.
item.description: The group had been using surveillance drones, but a recent attack that killed two Kurdish fighters highlighted its success in developing an effective new weapon.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL S. SCHMIDT and ERIC SCHMITT
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Hurricane Plunges a North Carolina Town’s Future Into Doubt
item.media:description: George Aubert rescuing one of his chickens from rising floodwaters in Fair Bluff.
item.description: The flooding after the storm had a special sting in Fair Bluff, N.C., which has tried with grit and heart to remake itself amid economic shifts.
item.dc:creator: JESS BIDGOOD and ALAN BLINDER

item.title: Your Daily Mini Crossword
item.description: Solve a bite-size crossword in just a few minutes.

item.title: After Torture, Ex-Detainee Is Still Captive of ‘The Darkness’
item.media:description: Suleiman Abdullah Salim endured beatings, sleep deprivation, water dousing and other severe measures.
item.media:credit: Bryan Denton for The New York Times
item.description: The United States subjected Suleiman Abdullah Salim to harsh tactics in a secret prison and held him without charge for years. He was found not to be a terrorist threat, but he pays a deep price to this day.
item.dc:creator: JAMES RISEN
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: How U.S. Torture Left a Legacy of Damaged Minds
item.media:credit: Bryan Denton for The New York Times
item.description: Beatings, sleep deprivation, menacing and other brutal tactics have led to persistent mental health problems among detainees held in secret C.I.A. prisons and at Guantánamo.
item.dc:creator: MATT APUZZO, SHERI FINK and JAMES RISEN

item.title: News: What We’re Reading
item.description: Get recommendations from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. Today, great reads from John Schwartz, Tyson Evans and others.
item.dc:creator: THE NEW YORK TIMES

item.title: A New Weapon in Russia’s Arsenal, and It’s Inflatable
item.description: The Russian military is using life-size decoy tanks, jets and missile launchers for disguise and deception.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW E. KRAMER

item.title: Feature: Generation Adderall
item.media:credit: Illustration by Chad Wys. Source image from the Getty’s Open Content Program. “Portrait of a Woman,” by Jacob Adriaensz Baker.
item.description: Like many of my friends, I spent years using prescription stimulants to get through school and start my career. Then I tried to get off them.
item.dc:creator: CASEY SCHWARTZ

item.title: Emerging Climate Accord Could Push A/C Out of Sweltering India’s Reach
item.media:description: Air-conditioning units in New Delhi.
item.description: A phaseout of hydrofluorocarbons could have a major effect on climate change but would make air-conditioning more expensive just as many Indians are becoming able to afford it.
item.dc:creator: ELLEN BARRY and CORAL DAVENPORT

item.title: How Bad Is Your Air-Conditioner for the Planet?
item.media:description: Monkeys on an air-conditioning unit in New Delhi in 2008.
item.description: Governments recently met to limit a chemical with a powerful heat trapping effect, highlighting air-conditioning’s complicated environmental impact.
item.dc:creator: TATIANA SCHLOSSBERG

item.title: Sports of The Times: In the Cubs’ Clubhouse, No Worries About a Curse or a Goat
item.media:description: The Cubs celebrated along with their manager, Joe Maddon, right.
item.description: The Chicago Cubs last won a world championship in 1908, when Teddy Roosevelt was president.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL POWELL

item.title: Cubs 6, Giants 5 | Chicago wins series, 3-1: Cubs Oust Giants to Reach N.L.C.S., for Once on Good Side of a Big Rally
item.media:description: The Cubs’ Ben Zobrist, right, with Jason Heyward, left, and Anthony Rizzo after scoring in the ninth inning.
item.description: A remarkable four-run rally in the ninth inning helped Chicago wrap up its division series with San Francisco.
item.dc:creator: BILLY WITZ

item.title: A Senate Hopeful Veers From Republican Mainstream, and Toward Donald Trump
item.media:description: Wendy E. Long, a Republican, is seeking to unseat Senator Chuck Schumer. She previously ran unsuccessfully against another Democrat, Senator Kirsten E. Gillibrand.
item.media:credit: Alex Wroblewski for The New York Times
item.description: Wendy E. Long, a former Supreme Court clerk and corporate litigator who is seeking to unseat Senator Charles Schumer, said Mr. Trump had shaped much of her current thinking.
item.dc:creator: VIVIAN YEE

item.title: Worries Over King Bhumibol Adulyadej’s Health Shake Thailand
item.media:description: People gathered on Wednesday to pray for King Bhumibol Adulyadej of Thailand outside the hospital in Bangkok where he was being treated.
item.media:credit: Adam Dean for The New York Times
item.description: The country’s prime minister returned abruptly to Bangkok and well-wishers waited at the hospital where the 88-year-old monarch was being treated.
item.dc:creator: RICHARD C. PADDOCK

item.title: F.B.I. Takes Over Investigation Into Fatal Plane Crash in Connecticut
item.media:description: Firefighters at the scene of the plane crash in East Hartford, Conn., on Tuesday.
item.media:credit: Jim Michaud/Journal Inquirer, via Associated Press
item.description: The National Transportation Safety Board said on Wednesday that its initial inquiry determined that the crash in East Hartford was the result of an intentional act.
item.dc:creator: MARC SANTORA

item.title: Toyota and Suzuki Say They Are Considering an Alliance
item.media:description: A Suzuki Ignis at the Paris Motor Show. Suzuki, which specializes in small cars, would benefit from Toyota’s scale and resources.
item.description: The Japanese car manufacturers were vague about what might happen but said that they were discussing a wide-ranging business partnership.
item.dc:creator: JONATHAN SOBLE

item.title: At Wells Fargo, Complaints About Fraudulent Accounts Since 2005
item.media:description: Yesenia Guitron said she was forced out by Wells Fargo after calling attention to a colleague who she said was opening accounts without customers’ consent.
item.media:credit: Talia Herman for The New York Times
item.description: Employees tipped off the bank’s ethics hotline, human resources department and even the chief executive, but the problems persisted.
item.dc:creator: STACY COWLEY

item.title: Why Samsung Abandoned Its Galaxy Note 7 Flagship Phone
item.description: The unprecedented move by the South Korean electronics giant is an embarrassing reversal for a respected global brand.
item.dc:creator: BRIAN X. CHEN and CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: Facebook Helped Drive a Voter Registration Surge, Election Officials Say
item.media:description: A voter registration event in Philadelphia in August.
item.description: A 17-word reminder displayed for four days in September contributed to substantial increases in online registration across the country.
item.dc:creator: NIRAJ CHOKSHI

item.title: Sinosphere: At Hong Kong Swearing-In, Some Lawmakers Pepper Their Oath With Jabs
item.media:description: Leung Kwok-hung ripped up a copy of the Chinese government’s restrictive ruling on Hong Kong election procedures after taking the oath of office in the Legislative Council on Wednesday. The yellow umbrella is a symbol of the 2014 pro-democracy protests.
item.description: The acts of defiance, directed at Beijing as some called for outright independence for the semiautonomous territory, seemed to augur a stormy legislative term.
item.dc:creator: ALAN WONG
item.category: Democratic Alliance for the Betterment and Progress of Hong Kong

item.title: ‘Clown Hysteria’ Spreads to Britain
item.description: A mix of childish pranks and more serious menacing appears to have migrated from the United States, leading to anti-clown patrols in parts of Britain.
item.dc:creator: DAN BILEFSKY

item.title: Tim Tebow Comforts Man Who Collapses After Game
item.media:description: Tim Tebow talking with a man who collapsed after Tebow’s Arizona Fall League game on Tuesday. Tebow stayed with the man for about 15 minutes.
item.media:credit: Rob Schumacher/The Arizona Republic, via Associated Press
item.description: After his Arizona Fall League debut, Tebow spent time with a man who appeared to have a seizure while waiting for his autograph.
item.dc:creator: KAREN CROUSE

item.title: Central Banks Consider Bitcoin’s Technology, if Not Bitcoin
item.media:description: Lael Brainard, the Federal Reserve governor overseeing new technology, says the decentralized method of record-keeping introduced by Bitcoin has the potential to transform multiple aspects of the financial system.
item.description: Central banks view the technology behind the virtual currency as a possible way to compete and record transactions, or to issue their own currencies.
item.dc:creator: NATHANIEL POPPER

item.title: Update: TripAdvisor to Stop Selling Tickets to Many Animal Attractions
item.media:description: Tourists riding elephants in the Chiang Mai province of Thailand.
item.description: TripAdvisor will no longer sell tickets to attractions like elephant rides and dolphin swims, a decision that could reshape how booking sites approach animal welfare.
item.dc:creator: JUSTIN SABLICH
item.category: People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals

item.title: Glenn Beck Says Opposing Trump Is ‘Moral, Ethical’ Even if It Means Clinton Wins
item.media:description: The radio personality Glenn Beck introducing Senator Ted Cruz at a campaign event in Davenport, Iowa, in January.
item.description: “If one helps to elect an immoral man to the highest office, then one is merely validating his immorality, lewdness, and depravity,” the conservative media personality wrote.
item.dc:creator: LIAM STACK

item.title: The Man Musicians Call When Two Tunes Sound Alike
item.media:description: Ed Sheeran, left, and Robin Thicke, right, have both been accused of copying aspects of musical work by Marvin Gaye, center.
item.media:credit: From left: Chad Batka for The New York Times; Jim Britt/Michael Ochs Archive, via Getty Images; Elizabeth Weinberg for The New York Times
item.description: Peter Oxendale, considered one of the world’s leading forensic musicologists, got into the profession by accident.
item.dc:creator: ALEX MARSHALL

item.title: Review: ‘Tower,’ About 1966, Before Mass Shootings Became Routine
item.media:description: The documentary “Tower” uses rotoscoping, an animation technique, to depict a time when mass gun violence could still stun America.
item.description: Keith Maitland’s documentary on the University of Texas tower mass shooting breathes life into victims rather than dissecting the shooter.
item.dc:creator: MANOHLA DARGIS

item.title: How ‘The Birth of a Nation’ Silences Black Women
item.media:description: Nate Parker and Aja Naomi King in “The Birth of a Nation.” The film continues the tradition of marginalizing black women in the recounting of Nat Turner’s insurrection.
item.description: The film tells of Nat Turner’s slave rebellion by using women’s trauma as motivation for the male hero, casting their victimization as secondary.
item.dc:creator: SALAMISHAH TILLET
